I was born and raised in Raider at number nine in the gardens and I was the second daughter of the family.
Your father was? My father was a blacksmith and I'm not sure, I think the man was just a housewife then.

moved from Raider to work at Winds, I'm not sure what it was, something to do with blacksmithing I would imagine.

She was owned by Gerald Morgan and his family. And I had worked there for a year.
And then my sister, who was already working in the chemists before me for one year, was going to teach a trade in college.
So T.C. Price very kindly asked her to ask me would I like the job?
Because he thought the work I was doing at Central Stores was too much for a young woman. So that's how I came to work in the chemists.

What do you remember of school?
I can't remember a lot of it.
I know I went to Cuntighver School.
And the only thing I can really remember of Cuntighver School,
that on your birthday, whoever was in the class had a birthday
the same day as you.
You had to sit on a chair with them,
and there was a lantern down Cuntighver somewhere,
and he sat by my side, and I wasn't very pleased.
I don't know why.
There we are.
That's all I can remember about Cuntighver School.
Then I went to Reader School.
And I think I was taught by...
Mr. Price.
Miss Farmer.
And Mrs. Owen.
She used to live at Glance Earth, or she left,
she was at Glance Earth, but she was on Glyfran before that.
I can remember that.
I don't remember.
Oh, and Miss Farmer.
If you didn't bring your sewing to school,
which they did sewing in those days, you know, embroidery,
she'd make you down her brother's socks.
I'm quite a good downer, actually.
Oh, well.
And is that where you got interested in knitting?
No, I think my mother taught me to knit.
And I think I got...
Jennifer's a good bit younger than me, my younger sister.
I used to knit for our dresser dolls.
So that's how I came about it.
But I still do knit, you know.
